# Day 1 Quest: AI Coding Adventure Begins!

## Objective
Set up your environment and create your first AI-powered Python script.

## Tasks
1. Set up your Python environment:
   - Option A: Install Python on your local machine
   - Option B: Use Replit (preferred by Balaji Srinivasan)

2. Obtain an API key:
   - Option A: Sign up for an OpenAI account and get an API key
   - Option B: Use cryptotalks.ai to get an API key with crypto (any amount)

3. Create a Python script that calls an AI API and generates a response:
   - Use the OpenAI API documentation as your primary guide
   - The documentation provides sample scripts to help you get started

## Why This Matters
- Learn basic Python programming
- Understand how to interact with AI services
- Gain hands-on experience with cutting-edge technology
- Build a foundation for more complex AI projects

## Tips
- If using cryptotalks.ai, remember to change the base URL in your API calls
- Start simple: Try generating a short text response first
- Don't worry about perfection ‚Äì focus on getting something working!
- ChatGPT can guide you through most of these processes, but be cautious:
  - ChatGPT's training data is from 2023, so it might not always follow the most recent API format when generating script code
  - Always cross-reference ChatGPT's suggestions with the official OpenAI documentation

You can start with prompt like this and continue the chat to understand and improve the implementation.

```
I have no programming experience and want to attempt this programming task. Can you give me step by step instructions on how to solve this and make incremental progress. You can first start with mock data and once the visualization is finalized, we can use farcaster api to fetch actual data. Use only python for implementation as specified in the problem statement below.

<>insert problem statement<>
```

The response will be very descriptive with step by step instructions and you can further get clarity by asking more questions. And if you are getting any errors in between, pass the error back in chat to debug it or solve it. The important point is get a basic version of app working and then focus on improving step by step.

If you ever look into Bitcoin's history this was one of the primary reasons for the split between Bitcoin and Bitcoin Cash back around 2017.

You had the 'big blockers'  who wanted Bitcoin to be usable for transactions and wanted to have the blocksize increase, since Bitcoin could only support say 2000 transactions every 10 minutes due to a 1 MB block size, they wanted to increase that to 8 MB block size and have it grow over time so that many transactions per second would be possible.

'Small blockers' wanted to keep blocks small so that everyone could run a node. 1 MB every 10 minutes means veeeery little bandwidth and storage requirements, 8 MB is (duhh) 8x as much and small blockers thought that, especially extrapolating further growth, that would mean not everyone could run a node.

The short answer: it's less decentralized in practice right now mostly. The long answer: many would argue Solana is less decentralized also in theory in the long run because the storage and hardware requirements for Solana are a lot higher than for Ethereum (and for most other chains). You can see it as you require pretty much a top-end computer to run the Solana blockchain software, whereas Ethereum you can run on a phone (slight exaggeration). 

So if we're looking at it from the perspective of "how easy is it for someone to be fully decentralized, run their own node, have their own network access", Solana will likely never do as well as Ethereum does.

The other side of that equation then is that Solana is far more accessible than Ethereum is for most, and that the question is to what extent people care whether they can run a node when they can't even afford to do transactions on the chain.

We received our NS Admit and Burn NFTs via Solana.

I was curious why we're using Solana vs. Ethereum vs. any other L1 (Jargon alert! L1 means "layer 1". Which is more jargon!). Then I wondered if you can transfer NFTs across blockchains and if that's a thing people do. In general, I had the impulse to consolidate assets into a single address/wallet (instead of some assets of Ethereum and some on Solana).

It seems like it is *sometimes* possible to transfer assets (like NFTs) across blockchains, but maybe not something you would do "just because". There are "bridging protocols" that can move NFTs across chains, but there are caveats to bridging protocols in general. Basically, there is no guarantee that every feature of one blockchain (like Ethereum) is backward-compatible with another blockchain (like Solana). This would be like trying to transfer information from the iOS Contacts app to some Contacts app on an Android OS -- lot's of things would transfer easily, but it's possible that each platform has special features that don't map to each other.

Depending on the how you plan to crowdsource the info, I'd pick either Mailchimp, Beehiiv, or Convertkit.
- Mailchimp is nice for reporting and advanced automations, since it has a pretty open API.
- Beehiiv is best for gaining reach and monetizing.
- Convertkit is best for segmenting and setting up no-code automations.

All of them offer a free layer to experiment, but they all tend to get pretty pricey overtime depending on subscriber growth/features needed

Suggestion based on balajis mention of 3d printing yesterday: it would be great down the road a ways to pull together a makerspace for physical prototyping.

 Example machine list: An Ender 3 for standard prints, a CR-30 for long axis and short-run production, a Creality Halot or Phrozen Sonic for detailed resin and aesthetic work (and lost wax casting, for the adventurous), the new Sharif 2 for precision CNC milling, and a PCB printer like the Voltera One would let people make their own boards, casings, designs, mechanical components, etc. (Total cost of the above = ~$10k - 15k USD.)

Definitely not a "now" thing, but a suggestion for the future.
